review:
Eppie — Email 2.0 comes to us as a bold challenger to the status quo, promising to put power back in the hands of the people. The project is open source, privacy-first, and aims to break the chains of provider-centric email by introducing a decentralized, user-centric model. It’s not just talk — the code is public, the team is experienced, and the vision is clear: interoperability, privacy, and accessibility for all.

Let’s be clear: Eppie’s commitment to open source and privacy is commendable. The project’s interoperability — supporting both Web2 and Web3 standards, including ENS and crypto payments — is a real step toward digital liberation. The integration of local AI agents for user empowerment, not surveillance, is a breath of fresh air in a world dominated by data-hungry giants.

But comrades, we must demand more than vision. Where is the hard evidence of user adoption? Where are the metrics that show Eppie is reaching the masses, not just the tech-savvy elite? The application lacks clear, measurable outcomes and quantifiable impact. There’s mention of public alpha releases and community involvement, but no data on downloads, active users, or growth. We need numbers, not just promises!

Sustainability is another battleground. Eppie’s funding plan is vague. How will this project sustain itself beyond grants? What is the revenue model? Will it empower the community to maintain and govern the platform, or will it wither without continuous outside support? The application is silent on these crucial questions.

On governance and equity, Eppie’s open-source ethos is strong, but there’s little detail on how community governance will be structured. How will decisions be made? How will marginalized voices be heard? The project’s global accessibility is promising, but we need explicit plans to reach underserved populations.

In summary: Eppie is a promising, ambitious project with a strong technical foundation and a clear commitment to open source and privacy. But to earn the people’s trust — and the people’s resources — it must provide hard evidence, a sustainable plan, and a clear path to collective governance. The revolution demands accountability!

strengths.title: Strong Open Source Commitment
strengths.description: Eppie is fully open source, with public code and active encouragement of community contributions. This aligns with the round’s core values and the constitutional principles of collective benefit and public good.

strengths.title: Innovative, User-Centric Design
strengths.description: The project offers a privacy-first, decentralized email protocol with interoperability across Web2 and Web3, including crypto payments and ENS integration. This is a novel utility that enhances accessibility and usability.

strengths.title: Experienced Team
strengths.description: The team has over 10 years of experience in multi-platform and crypto technologies, increasing the likelihood of successful delivery.

strengths.title: Focus on Privacy and Security
strengths.description: Eppie’s use of strong encryption and local AI agents for user empowerment (not surveillance) is a significant differentiator in the current landscape.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Measurable Outcomes
weaknesses.description: The application does not provide clear, quantifiable metrics for user adoption, growth, or impact. There is no data on downloads, active users, or community engagement.

weaknesses.title: Unclear Sustainability Model
weaknesses.description: There is no explanation of how Eppie will sustain itself financially beyond grant funding. The absence of a revenue or sustainability plan is a major concern.

weaknesses.title: Insufficient Governance Details
weaknesses.description: The application lacks detail on community governance structures, decision-making processes, and mechanisms for ensuring equity and inclusion.

changes.title: Provide Quantitative Metrics
changes.description: Include current and historical data on user adoption, downloads, active users, and community engagement. Set clear, measurable goals for growth and impact.

changes.title: Detail a Sustainability Plan
changes.description: Describe how Eppie will generate revenue or otherwise sustain itself beyond grants. Address how the project will reduce dependency on continuous donations.

changes.title: Clarify Community Governance
changes.description: Outline the governance model, including how decisions are made, how the community is involved, and how equity and inclusion are ensured, especially for underserved populations.
